Pictures

Bostonians show support

Daughters of Mary of Nazareth waited in line for tickets to the interfaith service outside Boston's Cathedral of the Holy Cross. David L. Ryan/ Globe Staff
People lined up early for free tickets to the service at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston. David L. Ryan/ Globe Staff
A student writes a message on a board outside BU's Marsh Chapel before a vigil for victmi Lingzi Lu. Julio Cortez/AP
Bruins fans sing the National Anthem during pre-game ceremonies. Jim Rogash/Getty Images
The Celtics, along with the Raptors and their fans, paid tribute to the victims of the bombings before tonight's game in Toronto. Reuters
For a few seconds, the sun reflected off of the Hancock Tower above the bomb site like a beacon of hope. Brita Ulf/Northeastern University student
Boston police officer Pat Duggan wrote in chalk outside a makeshift memorial along Newbury street. Shannon Stapleton/Reuters
People held patriotic balloons as they stood on a reopened portion of Boylston Street. Jessica Rinaldi/Reuters
Flowers and a card with a touching message were left on the gazebo near the race’s starting line. Michele McDonald for The Boston Globe
Ayk Oganesyan walked down Newbury Street with friends playing music blocks away from the bombing attack. Spencer Platt/Getty Images
The US flag was lowered at the White House to honor the victims of the explosions. Susan Walsh/Associated Press
Claire Winship (left) of Brighton embraced Keith Martin, who advertised free hugs on Boston Common. Wendy Maeda/Globe Staff
FBI crime scene investigators stood near an evidence marker on Boylston Street just past Berkeley Street. Darren McCollester / Getty Images
